title: WCAS LEGAL_ST 276-0-20 Introductory Topics in Legal Studies

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Legal_St 276-0-20 "Introductory Topics in Legal Studies: Law on the Frontier" Prof. Susan Gaunt Stearns, Winter 2016

This course examines the legal history of the American frontier, examining how legal institutions and practices spread across what would become the United States. From Jesse James to Chinese Exclusion, from polygamy to American Indian boarding schools, this course examines the presence and absence of the law in the west. Throughout the course, students will be engaged in building a website showcasing their research.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will be able to describe and analyze the controversy surrounding the term "frontier."
Students will analyze the interactions between race, class, and the law on the frontier.
Students will develop a chronology of U.S. policy related to American Indians.
Students will perform primary and secondary source research.
Students will learn to build websites and work collaboratively.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Evaluation will be based on discussion and website projects.
